PdfRendition flush	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">To manually flush a <code>PdfObject</code> behind this wrapper, you have to ensure\n that this object is added to the document, i.e. it has an indirect reference.\n Basically this means that before flushing you need to explicitly call <a href="../../../../../com/itextpdf/kernel/pdf/PdfObjectWrapper.html#makeIndirect-com.itextpdf.kernel.pdf.PdfDocument-"><code>PdfObjectWrapper.makeIndirect(PdfDocument)</code></a>.\n For example: wrapperInstance.makeIndirect(document).flush();\n Note that not every wrapper require this, only those that have such warning in documentation.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/PdfRendition.html

PdfShading.CoonsPatchMesh	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The class that extends PdfShading class and is in charge of Shading Dictionary with\n Coons Patch mesh type.\n\n This type of shading is constructed from one or more colour patches, each bounded by four cubic BÃ©zier curves.\n Degenerate BÃ©zier curves are allowed and are useful for certain graphical effects.\n At least one complete patch shall be specified.\n\n The shape of patch is defined by 12 control points.\n\n Colours are specified for each corner of the unit square,\n and bilinear interpolation is used to fill in colours over the entire unit square.\n\n Coordinates are mapped from the unit square into a four-sided patch whose sides are not necessarily linear.\n The mapping is continuous: the corners of the unit square map to corners of the patch\n and the sides of the unit square map to sides of the patch.\n\n For the format of data stream, that defines patches Table 85.\n\n If the shading dictionary contains a Function entry, the colour data for each corner of a patch\n shall be specified by a single parametric value t rather than by n separate colour components c1â¦cn.</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/PdfShading.CoonsPatchMesh.html

PdfShading.FreeFormGouraudShadedTriangleMesh setDecode	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Sets the <code>float[]</code> of numbers specifying how to map vertex coordinates and colour components\n into the appropriate ranges of values. The ranges shall be specified as follows:\n [x_min x_max y_min y_max c1_min c1_max â¦ cn_min cn_max].\n Only one pair of color values shall be specified if a Function entry is present.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/PdfShading.FreeFormGouraudShadedTriangleMesh.html
PdfShading.FreeFormGouraudShadedTriangleMesh	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The class that extends PdfShading class and is in charge of Shading Dictionary with\n free-form Gouraud-shaded triangle mesh type.\n\n The area to be shaded is defined by a path composed entirely of triangles.\n The colour at each vertex of the triangles is specified,\n and a technique known as Gouraud interpolation is used to colour the interiors.\n\n The object shall be represented as stream containing a sequence of vertex data.\n Each vertex is specified by the following values, in the order shown:\n f x y c1 â¦ cn where:\n f -  the vertexâs edge flag, that determines the vertex is connected to other vertices of the triangle mesh.\n      For full description Paragph 8.7.4.5.5\n x, y - vertexâs horizontal and vertical coordinates, expressed in the shadingâs target coordinate space.\n c1â¦cn - vertexâs colour components.\n\n If the shading dictionary includes a Function entry, only a single parametric value, t,\n shall be specified for each vertex in place of the colour components c1â¦cn.</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/PdfShading.FreeFormGouraudShadedTriangleMesh.html

PdfShading.LatticeFormGouraudShadedTriangleMesh	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The class that extends PdfShading class and is in charge of Shading Dictionary with\n lattice-form Gouraud-shaded triangle mesh type.\n\n This type is similar to PdfShading.FreeFormGouraudShadedTriangleMesh but instead of using free-form geometry,\n the vertices are arranged in a pseudorectangular lattice,\n which is topologically equivalent to a rectangular grid.\n The vertices are organized into rows, which need not be geometrically linear.\n\n The verticals data in stream is similar to PdfShading.FreeFormGouraudShadedTriangleMesh,\n except there is no edge flag.</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/PdfShading.LatticeFormGouraudShadedTriangleMesh.html

PdfSigner getSignatureAppearance	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Provides access to a signature appearance object. Use it to\n customize the appearance of the signature.\n <p>\n Be aware:\n <ul>\n<li>If you create new signature field (either use <a href="../../../com/itextpdf/signatures/PdfSigner.html#setFieldName-java.lang.String-"><code>setFieldName(java.lang.String)</code></a> with\n the name that doesn't exist in the document or don't specify it at all) then\n the signature is invisible by default.</li>\n<li>If you sign already existing field, then the signature appearance object\n is modified to have all the properties (page num., rect etc.) consistent with\n the state of the field (<strong>if you customized the appearance object\n before the <a href="../../../com/itextpdf/signatures/PdfSigner.html#setFieldName-java.lang.String-"><code>setFieldName(java.lang.String)</code></a> call you'll have to do it again</strong>)</li>\n</ul>\n</p></div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/PdfSigner.html

PdfSigner preClose	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">This is the first method to be called when using external signatures. The general sequence is:\n preClose(), getDocumentBytes() and close().\n <p>\n<code>exclusionSizes</code> must contain at least\n the <code>PdfName.CONTENTS</code> key with the size that it will take in the\n document. Note that due to the hex string coding this size should be byte_size*2+2.</p></div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/PdfSigner.html
PdfSigner getRangeStream	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Gets the document bytes that are hashable when using external signatures.\n The general sequence is:\n <a href="../../../com/itextpdf/signatures/PdfSigner.html#preClose-java.util.Map-"><code>preClose(Map)</code></a>, <a href="../../../com/itextpdf/signatures/PdfSigner.html#getRangeStream--"><code>getRangeStream()</code></a> and <a href="../../../com/itextpdf/signatures/PdfSigner.html#close-com.itextpdf.kernel.pdf.PdfDictionary-"><code>close(PdfDictionary)</code></a>.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/PdfSigner.html

The general sequence is:\n preClose(), getDocumentBytes() and close().\n <p>\n update is a PdfDictionary that must have exactly the\n same keys as the ones provided in <a href="../../../com/itextpdf/signatures/PdfSigner.html#preClose-java.util.Map-"><code>preClose(Map)</code></a>.</p></div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/PdfSigner.html

PdfStream PdfStream	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Creates an efficient stream. No temporary array is ever created. PdfString	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>A PdfString-class is the PDF-equivalent of a\n JAVA-String-object.\n \n A string is a sequence of characters delimited by parenthesis.\n If a string is too long to be conveniently placed on a single line, it may\n be split across multiple lines by using the backslash character (\) at the\n end of a line to indicate that the string continues on the following line.\n Within a string, the backslash character is used as an escape to specify\n unbalanced parenthesis, non-printing ASCII characters, and the backslash\n character itself. Use of the \ddd escape sequence is the preferred\n way to represent characters outside the printable ASCII character set.\n This object is described in the 'Portable Document Format Reference Manual\n version 1.7' section 3.2.3 (page 53-56).\n \nPdfObject</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/PdfString.html

RoundDotsBorder draw	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block"><p>\n All borders are supposed to be drawn in such way, that inner content of the element is on the right from the\n drawing direction. Borders are drawn in this order: top, right, bottom, left.\n </p>\n<p>\n Given points specify the line which lies on the border of the content area,\n therefore the border itself should be drawn to the left from the drawing direction.\n </p>\n<p>\n<code>borderWidthBefore</code> and <code>borderWidthAfter</code> parameters are used to\n define the widths of the borders that are before and after the current border, e.g. for\n the bottom border, <code>borderWidthBefore</code> specifies width of the right border and\n <code>borderWidthAfter</code> - width of the left border. Those width are used to handle areas\n of border joins.\n </p></div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/RoundDotsBorder.html

Table complete	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Indicates that all the desired content has been added to this large element.\n After this method is called, more precise rendering is activated.\n For instance, a table may have a <a href="../../../../com/itextpdf/layout/element/Table.html#setSkipLastFooter-boolean-"><code>setSkipLastFooter(boolean)</code></a> method set to true,\n and in case of large table on <a href="../../../../com/itextpdf/layout/element/Table.html#flush--"><code>flush()</code></a> we do not know if any more content will be added,\n so we might not place the content in the bottom of the page where it would fit, but instead add a footer, and\n place that content in the start of the page. Technically such result would look all right, but it would be\n more concise if we placed the content in the bottom and did not start new page. For such cases to be\n renderered more accurately, one can call <a href="../../../../com/itextpdf/layout/element/Table.html#complete--"><code>complete()</code></a> when some content is still there and not flushed.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/Table.html

TagStructureContext flushPageTags	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Flushes the tags which are considered to belong to the given page.\n The logic that defines if the given tag (structure element) belongs to the page is the following:\n if all the marked content references (dictionary or number references), that are the\n descenders of the given structure element, belong to the current page - the tag is considered\n to belong to the page. If tag has descenders from several pages - it is flushed, if all other pages except the\n current one are flushed.\n\n <br><br>\n If some of the page's tags are still connected to the accessible elements, in this case these tags are considered\n as not yet finished ones, and they won't be flushed.</br></br></div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/TagStructureContext.html
TagStructureContext normalizeDocumentRootTag	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Transforms root tags in a way that complies with the PDF References.\n\n <br/><br/>\n PDF Reference\n 10.7.3 Grouping Elements:\n\n <br/><br/>\n For most content extraction formats, the document must be a tree with a single top-level element;\n the structure tree root (identified by the StructTreeRoot entry in the document catalog) must have\n only one child in its K (kids) array. If the PDF file contains a complete document, the structure\n type Document is recommended for this top-level element in the logical structure hierarchy. If the\n file contains a well-formed document fragment, one of the structure types Part, Art, Sect, or Div\n may be used instead.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/TagStructureContext.html
TagStructureContext	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>TagStructureContext class is used to track necessary information of document's tag structure.\n It is also used to make some global modifications of the tag tree like removing or flushing page tags, however\n these two methods and also others are called automatically and are for the most part for internal usage.\n \n There shall be only one instance of this class per PdfDocument. To obtain instance of this class use\n PdfDocument.getTagStructureContext().</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/TagStructureContext.html

TagTreePointer setPageForTagging	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Sets a page which content will be tagged with this instance of <code>TagTreePointer</code>.\n To tag page content:\n <ol>\n<li>Set pointer position to the tag which will be the parent of the page content item;</li>\n<li>Call <a href="../../../../../com/itextpdf/kernel/pdf/tagutils/TagTreePointer.html#getTagReference--"><code>getTagReference()</code></a> to obtain the reference to the current tag;</li>\n<li>Pass <code>PdfTagReference</code> to the <a href="../../../../../com/itextpdf/kernel/pdf/canvas/PdfCanvas.html#openTag-com.itextpdf.kernel.pdf.tagutils.TagReference-"><code>PdfCanvas.openTag(TagReference)</code></a> method of the page's <a href="../../../../../com/itextpdf/kernel/pdf/canvas/PdfCanvas.html" title="class in com.itextpdf.kernel.pdf.canvas"><code>PdfCanvas</code></a> to start marked content item;</li>\n<li>Draw content on <code>PdfCanvas</code>;</li>\n<li>Use <a href="../../../../../com/itextpdf/kernel/pdf/canvas/PdfCanvas.html#closeTag--"><code>PdfCanvas.closeTag()</code></a> to finish marked content item.</li>\n</ol></div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/TagTreePointer.html
TagTreePointer setContentStreamForTagging	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Sometimes, tags are desired to be connected with the content that resides not in the page's content stream,\n but rather in the some appearance stream or in the form xObject stream. In that case, to have a valid tag structure,\n one shall set not only the page, on which the content will be rendered, but also the content stream in which\n the tagged content will reside.\n <br><br>\n NOTE: It's important to set a <code>null</code> for this value, when tagging of this stream content is finished.</br></br></div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/TagTreePointer.html

TagTreePointer addTag	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Adds a new tag to the tag structure.\n This method call moves this <code>TagTreePointer</code> to the added kid.\n <br/>\n New tag will have a role and attributes defined by the given IAccessibleElement.\n <br><br>\n If <i>keepConnectedToTag</i> is true then a newly created tag will retain the connection with given\n accessible element. TagTreePointer addTag	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Adds a new tag to the tag structure.\n This method call moves this <code>TagTreePointer</code> to the added kid.\n <br/>\n New tag will have a role and attributes defined by the given IAccessibleElement.\n <br><br>\n If  is true then a newly created tag will retain the connection with given\n accessible element. TagTreePointer setNextNewKidIndex	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Sets index of the next added to the current tag kid, which could be another tag or content item.\n By default, new tag is added at the end of the parent kids array. TagTreePointer moveToTag	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Moves this <code>TagTreePointer</code> instance to a tag, which is connected with the given accessible element.\n <p>\n<br/><br/>\n The connection between the tag and the accessible element instance is used as a sign that tag is not yet finished\n and therefore should not be flushed or removed if page tags are flushed or removed. Also, any <code>TagTreePointer</code>\n could be immediately moved to the tag with connection via it's connected element by using this method. If accessible\n element is connected to the tag, then all changes of the role or properties of the element will affect the connected\n tag role and properties.\n <br/>\n For any existing not connected tag the connection could be created using <a href="../../../../../com/itextpdf/kernel/pdf/tagutils/TagTreePointer.html#getConnectedElement-boolean-"><code>getConnectedElement(boolean)</code></a>\n with <i>true</i> as parameter.</p></div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/TagTreePointer.html

TagTreePointer	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>TagTreePointer class is used to modify the document's tag tree. At any given moment, instance of this class\n 'points' at the specific position in the tree (at the specific tag). For the current tag you can add new tags, modify\n it's role and properties, etc. Also, using instance of this class, you can change tag position in the tag structure,\n you can flush current tag or remove it.\n \n\n There could be any number of the instances of this class, simultaneously pointing to different (or the same) parts of\n the tag structure. Because of this, you can for example remove the tag at which another instance is currently pointing.\n In this case, this another instance becomes invalid, and invocation of any method on it will result in exception. To make\n given instance valid again, use moveToRoot() method.</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/TagTreePointer.html
TernaryTree lo	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Pointer to low branch and to rest of the key when it is\n stored directly in this node, we don't have unions in java!</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/TernaryTree.html

TernaryTree eq	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Pointer to equal branch and to data when this node is a string terminator.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/TernaryTree.html
TernaryTree sc	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block"><p>The character stored in this node: splitchar.\n Two special values are reserved:</p>\n<ul><li>0x0000 as string terminator</li>\n<li>0xFFFF to indicate that the branch starting at\n this node is compressed</li></ul>\n<p>This shouldn't be a problem if we give the usual semantics to\n strings since 0xFFFF is garanteed not to be an Unicode character.</p></div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/TernaryTree.html
TernaryTree kv	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">This vector holds the trailing of the keys when the branch is compressed.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/TernaryTree.html

TernaryTree insert	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Branches are initially compressed, needing\n one node per key plus the size of the string\n key. They are decompressed as needed when\n another key with same prefix\n is inserted. This saves a lot of space,\n specially for long keys.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/TernaryTree.html

TernaryTree insertBalanced	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Recursively insert the median first and then the median of the\n lower and upper halves, and so on in order to get a balanced\n tree. The array of keys is assumed to be sorted in ascending\n order.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/TernaryTree.html
TernaryTree balance	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Balance the tree for best search performance</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/TernaryTree.html
TernaryTree trimToSize	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Each node stores a character (splitchar) which is part of\n some key(s). In a compressed branch (one that only contain\n a single string key) the trailer of the key which is not\n already in nodes is stored  externally in the kv array.\n As items are inserted, key substrings decrease.\n Some substrings may completely  disappear when the whole\n branch is totally decompressed.\n The tree is traversed to find the key substrings actually\n used. In addition, duplicate substrings are removed using\n a map (implemented with a TernaryTree!).</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/TernaryTree.html
TernaryTree	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Ternary Search Tree.\nA ternary search tree is a hibrid between a binary tree and\n a digital search tree (trie). Keys are limited to strings.\n A data value of type char is stored in each leaf node.\n It can be used as an index (or pointer) to the data.\n Branches that only contain one key are compressed to one node\n by storing a pointer to the trailer substring of the key.\n This class is intended to serve as base class or helper class\n to implement Dictionary collections or the like. Ternary trees\n have some nice properties as the following: the tree can be\n traversed in sorted order, partial matches (wildcard) can be\n implemented, retrieval of all keys within a given distance\n from the target, etc. The storage requirements are higher than\n a binary tree but a lot less than a trie. Performance is\n comparable with a hash table, sometimes it outperforms a hash\n function (most of the time can determine a miss faster than a hash).\nThe main purpose of this java port is to serve as a base for\n implementing TeX's hyphenation algorithm (see The TeXBook,\n appendix H). Each language requires from 5000 to 15000 hyphenation\n patterns which will be keys in this tree. The strings patterns\n are usually small (from 2 to 5 characters), but each char in the\n tree is stored in a node. Thus memory usage is the main concern.\n We will sacrify 'elegance' to keep memory requirements to the\n minimum. Using java's char type as pointer (yes, I know pointer\n it is a forbidden word in java) we can keep the size of the node\n to be just 8 bytes (3 pointers and the data char). This gives\n room for about 65000 nodes. In my tests the english patterns\n took 7694 nodes and the german patterns 10055 nodes,\n so I think we are safe.\nAll said, this is a map with strings as keys and char as value.\n Pretty limited!. It can be extended to a general map by\n using the string representation of an object and using the\n char value as an index to an array that contains the object\n values.\nThis work was authored by Carlos Villegas (cav@uniscope.co.jp).</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/TernaryTree.html
Text getText	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Gets the contents of the Text object that will be rendered.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/Text.html

TIFFDirectory getIFDOffset	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Returns the offset of the IFD corresponding to this\n <code>TIFFDirectory</code>.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/TIFFDirectory.html
TIFFDirectory	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>A class representing an Image File Directory (IFD) from a TIFF 6.0\n stream.  The TIFF file format is described in more detail in the\n comments for the TIFFDescriptor class.\n \n A TIFF IFD consists of a set of TIFFField tags.  Methods are\n provided to query the set of tags and to obtain the raw field\n array.  In addition, convenience methods are provided for acquiring\n the values of tags that contain a single value that fits into a\n byte, int, long, float, or double.\n \n Every TIFF file is made up of one or more public IFDs that are\n joined in a linked list, rooted in the file header.  A file may\n also contain so-called private IFDs that are referenced from\n tag data and do not appear in the main list.\n \n This class is not a committed part of the JAI API.  It may\n be removed or changed in future releases of JAI.</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/TIFFDirectory.html
TIFFFaxDecoder reverseBits	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Reverses the bits in the array</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/TIFFFaxDecoder.html
TIFFFaxDecoder	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Class that can decode TIFF files.</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/TIFFFaxDecoder.html
TIFFFaxDecompressor fillOrder	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">The logical order of bits within a byte.\n <pre>\n 1 = MSB-to-LSB\n 2 = LSB-to-MSB (flipped)\n </pre></div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/TIFFFaxDecompressor.html
TIFFFaxDecompressor uncompressedMode	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Uncompressed mode flag: 1 if uncompressed, 0 if not.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/TIFFFaxDecompressor.html
TIFFFaxDecompressor fillBits	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">EOL padding flag: 1 if fill bits have been added before an EOL such\n that the EOL ends on a byte boundary, 0 otherwise.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/TIFFFaxDecompressor.html
TIFFFaxDecompressor oneD	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Coding dimensionality: 1 for 2-dimensional, 0 for 1-dimensional.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/TIFFFaxDecompressor.html
TIFFFaxDecompressor SetOptions	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Invokes the superclass method and then sets instance variables on\n the basis of the metadata set on this decompressor.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/TIFFFaxDecompressor.html

TIFFField getType	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Returns the type of the data stored in the IFD.\n For a TIFF6.0 file, the value will equal one of the\n TIFF_ constants defined in this class.  For future\n revisions of TIFF, higher values are possible.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/TIFFField.html

TIFFField getAsBytes	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Returns the data as an uninterpreted array of bytes.\n The type of the field must be one of TIFF_BYTE, TIFF_SBYTE,\n or TIFF_UNDEFINED;\n\n <p> For data in TIFF_BYTE format, the application must take\n care when promoting the data to longer integral types\n to avoid sign extension.\n\n <p> A ClassCastException will be thrown if the field is not\n of type TIFF_BYTE, TIFF_SBYTE, or TIFF_UNDEFINED.</p></p></div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/TIFFField.html

TIFFField getAsInt	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Returns data in TIFF_BYTE, TIFF_SBYTE, TIFF_UNDEFINED, TIFF_SHORT,\n TIFF_SSHORT, or TIFF_SLONG format as an int.\n\n <p> TIFF_BYTE and TIFF_UNDEFINED data are treated as unsigned;\n that is, no sign extension will take place and the returned\n value will be in the range [0, 255].  TIFF_SBYTE data will\n be returned in the range [-128, 127].\n\n <p> A ClassCastException will be thrown if the field is not of\n type TIFF_BYTE, TIFF_SBYTE, TIFF_UNDEFINED, TIFF_SHORT,\n TIFF_SSHORT, or TIFF_SLONG.</p></p></div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/TIFFField.html

TIFF_SBYTE data will\n be returned in the range [-128, 127].\n\n <p> A ClassCastException will be thrown if the field is not of\n type TIFF_BYTE, TIFF_SBYTE, TIFF_UNDEFINED, TIFF_SHORT,\n TIFF_SSHORT, TIFF_SLONG, or TIFF_LONG.</p></p></div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/TIFFField.html
TIFFField getAsFloat	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Returns data in any numerical format as a float.  Data in\n TIFF_SRATIONAL or TIFF_RATIONAL format are evaluated by\n dividing the numerator into the denominator using\n double-precision arithmetic and then truncating to single\n precision.  Data in TIFF_SLONG, TIFF_LONG, or TIFF_DOUBLE\n format may suffer from truncation.\n\n <p> A ClassCastException will be thrown if the field is\n of type TIFF_UNDEFINED or TIFF_ASCII.</p></div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/TIFFField.html

TIFFField	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>A class representing a field in a TIFF 6.0 Image File Directory.\n\n  The TIFF file format is described in more detail in the\n comments for the TIFFDescriptor class.\n\n  A field in a TIFF Image File Directory (IFD).  A field is defined\n as a sequence of values of identical data type.  TIFF 6.0 defines\n 12 data types, which are mapped internally onto the Java data types\n byte, int, long, float, and double.\n\n  This class is not a committed part of the JAI API.  It may\n be removed or changed in future releases of JAI.</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/TIFFField.html

XMPDateTime hasTime	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">This flag is set either by parsing or by setting hours, minutes, seconds or milliseconds.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPDateTime.html
XMPDateTime hasTimeZone	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">This flag is set either by parsing or by setting hours, minutes, seconds or milliseconds.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPDateTime.html
XMPDateTime	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The XMPDateTime-class represents a point in time up to a resolution of nano\n seconds. Dates and time in the serialized XMP are ISO 8601 strings. There are utility functions\n to convert to the ISO format, a Calendar or get the Timezone. The fields of\n XMPDateTime are:\n \n month - The month in the range 1..12.\n  day - The day of the month in the range 1..31.\n  minute - The minute in the range 0..59.\n  hour - The time zone hour in the range 0..23.\n  minute - The time zone minute in the range 0..59.\n  nanoSecond - The nano seconds within a second. Note: if the XMPDateTime is\n converted into a calendar, the resolution is reduced to milli seconds.\n  timeZone - a TimeZone-object.\n \n DateTime values are occasionally used in cases with only a date or only a time component. A date\n without a time has zeros for all the time fields. A time without a date has zeros for all date\n fields (year, month, and day).</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPDateTime.html

XMPException XMPException	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Constructs an exception with a message and an error code.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPException.html

XMPIterator skipSubtree	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Skip the subtree below the current node when <code>next()</code> is\n called.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPIterator.html
XMPIterator	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Interface for the XMPMeta iteration services.\n XMPIterator provides a uniform means to iterate over the\n schema and properties within an XMP object.\n \n The iteration over the schema and properties within an XMP object is very\n complex. It is helpful to have a thorough understanding of the XMP data tree.\n One way to learn this is to create some complex XMP and examine the output of\n XMPMeta#toString. This is also described in the XMP\n Specification, in the XMP Data Model chapter.\n \n The top of the XMP data tree is a single root node. This does not explicitly\n appear in the dump and is never visited by an iterator (that is, it is never\n returned from XMPIterator#next()). Beneath the root are\n schema nodes. These are just collectors for top level properties in the same\n namespace. They are created and destroyed implicitly. Beneath the schema\n nodes are the property nodes. The nodes below a property node depend on its\n type (simple, struct, or array) and whether it has qualifiers.\n \n An XMPIterator is created by XMPMeta#interator() constructor\n defines a starting point for the iteration and options that control how it\n proceeds. By default the iteration starts at the root and visits all nodes\n beneath it in a depth first manner. The root node is not visited, the first\n visited node is a schema node. You can provide a schema name or property path\n to select a different starting node. By default this visits the named root\n node first then all nodes beneath it in a depth first manner.\n \n The XMPIterator#next() method delivers the schema URI, path,\n and option flags for the node being visited. If the node is simple it also\n delivers the value. Qualifiers for this node are visited next. The fields of\n a struct or items of an array are visited after the qualifiers of the parent.\n \n The options to control the iteration are:\n \nJUST_CHILDREN - Visit just the immediate children of the root. Skip\n the root itself and all nodes below the immediate children. This omits the\n qualifiers of the immediate children, the qualifier nodes being below what\n they qualify, default is to visit the complete subtree.\n JUST_LEAFNODES - Visit just the leaf property nodes and their\n qualifiers.\n JUST_LEAFNAME - Return just the leaf component of the node names.\n The default is to return the full xmp path.\n OMIT_QUALIFIERS - Do not visit the qualifiers.\n INCLUDE_ALIASES - Adds known alias properties to the properties in the iteration.\n                Note: Not supported in Java XMPCore! \n \n\nnext() returns XMPPropertyInfo-objects and throws\n a NoSuchElementException if there are no more properties to\n return.</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPIterator.html
XMPIteratorImpl skipSiblings	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">flag to indicate that skipSiblings() has been called.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPIteratorImpl.html
XMPIteratorImpl skipSubtree	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block"><span class="descfrmTypeLabel">Description copied from interface: <code><a href="../../../../../com/itextpdf/kernel/xmp/XMPIterator.html#skipSubtree--">XMPIterator</a></code></span></div><br><br><div class="block">Skip the subtree below the current node when <code>next()</code> is\n called.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPIteratorImpl.html
XMPIteratorImpl skipSiblings	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block"><span class="descfrmTypeLabel">Description copied from interface: <code><a href="../../../../../com/itextpdf/kernel/xmp/XMPIterator.html#skipSiblings--">XMPIterator</a></code></span></div><br><br><div class="block">Skip the subtree below and remaining siblings of the current node when\n <code>next()</code> is called.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPIteratorImpl.html
XMPIteratorImpl	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The XMPIterator implementation.\n Iterates the XMP Tree according to a set of options.\n During the iteration the XMPMeta-object must not be changed.\n Calls to skipSubtree() / skipSiblings() will affect the iteration.</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPIteratorImpl.html
XMPMeta getProperty	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">The property value getter-methods all take a property specification: the first two parameters\n are always the top level namespace URI (the "schema" namespace) and the basic name\n of the property being referenced. See the introductory discussion of path expression usage\n for more information.\n <p>\n All of the functions return an object inherited from <code>PropertyBase</code> or\n <code>null</code> if the property does not exists. The result object contains the value of\n the property and option flags describing the property. Arrays and the non-leaf levels of\n nodes do not have values.\n <p>\n See <a href="../../../../com/itextpdf/kernel/xmp/options/PropertyOptions.html" title="class in com.itextpdf.kernel.xmp.options"><code>PropertyOptions</code></a> for detailed information about the options.\n <p>\n This is the simplest property getter, mainly for top level simple properties or after using\n the path composition functions in XMPPathFactory.</p></p></p></div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html
XMPMeta getArrayItem	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Provides access to items within an array. The index is passed as an integer, you need not\n worry about the path string syntax for array items, convert a loop index to a string, etc.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html
XMPMeta countArrayItems	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Returns the number of items in the array.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html
XMPMeta getStructField	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Provides access to fields within a nested structure. The namespace for the field is passed as\n a URI, you need not worry about the path string syntax.\n <p>\n The names of fields should be XML qualified names, that is within an XML namespace. The path\n syntax for a qualified name uses the namespace prefix. This is unreliable since the prefix is\n never guaranteed. The URI is the formal name, the prefix is just a local shorthand in a given\n sequence of XML text.</p></div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html
XMPMeta getQualifier	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Provides access to a qualifier attached to a property. The namespace for the qualifier is\n passed as a URI, you need not worry about the path string syntax. In many regards qualifiers\n are like struct fields. See the introductory discussion of qualified properties for more\n information.\n <p>\n The names of qualifiers should be XML qualified names, that is within an XML namespace. The\n path syntax for a qualified name uses the namespace prefix. This is unreliable since the\n prefix is never guaranteed. The URI is the formal name, the prefix is just a local shorthand\n in a given sequence of XML text.\n <p>\n<em>Note:</em> Qualifiers are only supported for simple leaf properties at this time.</p></p></div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html
XMPMeta setProperty	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">The property value <code>setters</code> all take a property specification, their\n differences are in the form of this. The first two parameters are always the top level\n namespace URI (the <code>schema</code> namespace) and the basic name of the property being\n referenced. See the introductory discussion of path expression usage for more information.\n <p>\n All of the functions take a string value for the property and option flags describing the\n property. The value must be Unicode in UTF-8 encoding. Arrays and non-leaf levels of structs\n do not have values. Empty arrays and structs may be created using appropriate option flags.\n All levels of structs that is assigned implicitly are created if necessary. appendArayItem\n implicitly creates the named array if necessary.\n <p>\n See <a href="../../../../com/itextpdf/kernel/xmp/options/PropertyOptions.html" title="class in com.itextpdf.kernel.xmp.options"><code>PropertyOptions</code></a> for detailed information about the options.\n <p>\n This is the simplest property setter, mainly for top level simple properties or after using\n the path composition functions in <a href="../../../../com/itextpdf/kernel/xmp/XMPPathFactory.html" title="class in com.itextpdf.kernel.xmp"><code>XMPPathFactory</code></a>.</p></p></p></div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html
XMPMeta setArrayItem	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Replaces an item within an array. The index is passed as an integer, you need not worry about\n the path string syntax for array items, convert a loop index to a string, etc. The array\n passed must already exist. In normal usage the selected array item is modified. A new item is\n automatically appended if the index is the array size plus 1.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html

In normal usage the selected array item is\n modified. A new item is automatically appended if the index is the array size plus 1.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html
XMPMeta appendArrayItem	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Simplifies the construction of an array by not requiring that you pre-create an empty array.\n The array that is assigned is created automatically if it does not yet exist. Each call to\n appendArrayItem() appends an item to the array. The corresponding parameters have the same\n use as setArrayItem(). The arrayOptions parameter is used to specify what kind of array. If\n the array exists, it must have the specified form.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html

The path syntax for a qualified name uses\n the namespace prefix, which is unreliable because the prefix is never guaranteed. The URI is\n the formal name, the prefix is just a local shorthand in a given sequence of XML text.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html
XMPMeta setQualifier	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Provides access to a qualifier attached to a property. The namespace for the qualifier is\n passed as a URI, you need not worry about the path string syntax. In many regards qualifiers\n are like struct fields. See the introductory discussion of qualified properties for more\n information. The names of qualifiers should be XML qualified names, that is within an XML\n namespace. The path syntax for a qualified name uses the namespace prefix, which is\n unreliable because the prefix is never guaranteed. The URI is the formal name, the prefix is\n just a local shorthand in a given sequence of XML text. The property the qualifier\n will be attached has to exist.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html

XMPMeta doesQualifierExist	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">DoesQualifierExist tells if the qualifier exists.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html
XMPMeta getLocalizedText	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">These functions provide convenient support for localized text properties, including a number\n of special and obscure aspects. Localized text properties are stored in alt-text arrays. They\n allow multiple concurrent localizations of a property value, for example a document title or\n copyright in several languages. The most important aspect of these functions is that they\n select an appropriate array item based on one or two RFC 3066 language tags. One of these\n languages, the "specific" language, is preferred and selected if there is an exact match. For\n many languages it is also possible to define a "generic" language that may be used if there\n is no specific language match. The generic language must be a valid RFC 3066 primary subtag,\n or the empty string. For example, a specific language of "en-US" should be used in the US,\n and a specific language of "en-UK" should be used in England. It is also appropriate to use\n "en" as the generic language in each case. If a US document goes to England, the "en-US"\n title is selected by using the "en" generic language and the "en-UK" specific language. It is\n considered poor practice, but allowed, to pass a specific language that is just an RFC 3066\n primary tag. For example "en" is not a good specific language, it should only be used as a\n generic language. Passing "i" or "x" as the generic language is also considered poor practice\n but allowed. Advice from the W3C about the use of RFC 3066 language tags can be found at:\n http://www.w3.org/International/articles/language-tags/\n <p>\n<em>Note:</em> RFC 3066 language tags must be treated in a case insensitive manner. The XMP\n Toolkit does this by normalizing their capitalization:\n <ul>\n<li> The primary subtag is lower case, the suggested practice of ISO 639.\n <li> All 2 letter secondary subtags are upper case, the suggested practice of ISO 3166.\n <li> All other subtags are lower case. The XMP specification defines an artificial language,\n <li>"x-default", that is used to explicitly denote a default item in an alt-text array.\n </li></li></li></li></ul>\n The XMP toolkit normalizes alt-text arrays such that the x-default item is the first item.\n The SetLocalizedText function has several special features related to the x-default item, see\n its description for details. The selection of the array item is the same for GetLocalizedText\n and SetLocalizedText:\n <ul>\n<li> Look for an exact match with the specific language.\n <li> If a generic language is given, look for a partial match.\n <li> Look for an x-default item.\n <li> Choose the first item.\n </li></li></li></li></ul>\n A partial match with the generic language is where the start of the item's language matches\n the generic string and the next character is '-'. An exact match is also recognized as a\n degenerate case. It is fine to pass x-default as the specific language. In this case,\n selection of an x-default item is an exact match by the first rule, not a selection by the\n 3rd rule. The last 2 rules are fallbacks used when the specific and generic languages fail to\n produce a match. <code>getLocalizedText</code> returns information about a selected item in\n an alt-text array. The array item is selected according to the rules given above.\n\n <em>Note:</em> In a future version of this API a method\n                using Java <code>java.lang.Locale</code> will be added.</p></div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html
XMPMeta setLocalizedText	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Modifies the value of a selected item in an alt-text array. Creates an appropriate array item\n if necessary, and handles special cases for the x-default item. If the selected item is from\n a match with the specific language, the value of that item is modified. If the existing value\n of that item matches the existing value of the x-default item, the x-default item is also\n modified. If the array only has 1 existing item (which is not x-default), an x-default item\n is added with the given value. If the selected item is from a match with the generic language\n and there are no other generic matches, the value of that item is modified. If the existing\n value of that item matches the existing value of the x-default item, the x-default item is\n also modified. If the array only has 1 existing item (which is not x-default), an x-default\n item is added with the given value. If the selected item is from a partial match with the\n generic language and there are other partial matches, a new item is created for the specific\n language. The x-default item is not modified. If the selected item is from the last 2 rules\n then a new item is created for the specific language. If the array only had an x-default\n item, the x-default item is also modified. If the array was empty, items are created for the\n specific language and x-default.\n\n <em>Note:</em> In a future version of this API a method\n                using Java <code>java.lang.Locale</code> will be added.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html
XMPMeta getPropertyBoolean	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">These are very similar to <code>getProperty()</code> and <code>SetProperty()</code> above,\n but the value is returned or provided in a literal form instead of as a UTF-8 string.\n The path composition functions in <code>XMPPathFactory</code> may be used to compose an path\n expression for fields in nested structures, items in arrays, or qualifiers.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html
XMPMeta getPropertyInteger	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Convenience method to retrieve the literal value of a property.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html

XMPMeta getPropertyDouble	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Convenience method to retrieve the literal value of a property.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html
XMPMeta getPropertyDate	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Convenience method to retrieve the literal value of a property.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html
XMPMeta getPropertyCalendar	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Convenience method to retrieve the literal value of a property.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html
XMPMeta getPropertyBase64	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Convenience method to retrieve the literal value of a property.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html

XMPMeta sort	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Sorts the complete datamodel according to the following rules:\n <ul>\n<li>Schema nodes are sorted by prefix.\n                <li>Properties at top level and within structs are sorted by full name, that is\n                        prefix + local name.\n                <li>Array items are not sorted, even if they have no certain order such as bags.\n                <li>Qualifier are sorted, with the exception of "xml:lang" and/or "rdf:type"\n                        that stay at the top of the list in that order.\n </li></li></li></li></ul></div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html
XMPMeta normalize	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Perform the normalization as a separate parsing step.\n Normally it is done during parsing, unless the parsing option\n <a href="../../../../com/itextpdf/kernel/xmp/options/ParseOptions.html#OMIT_NORMALIZATION"><code>ParseOptions.OMIT_NORMALIZATION</code></a> is set to <code>true</code>.\n <em>Note:</em> It does no harm to call this method to an already normalized xmp object.\n It was a PDF/A requirement to get hand on the unnormalized <code>XMPMeta</code> object.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html
XMPMeta	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>This class represents the set of XMP metadata as a DOM representation. It has methods to read and\n modify all kinds of properties, create an iterator over all properties and serialize the metadata\n to a String, byte-array or OutputStream.</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html

XMPMetaFactory parse	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">These functions support parsing serialized RDF into an XMP object, and serailizing an XMP\n object into RDF. The input for parsing may be any valid Unicode\n encoding. ISO Latin-1 is also recognized, but its use is strongly discouraged. Serialization\n is always as UTF-8.\n <p></p>\n<code>parseFromBuffer()</code> parses RDF from an <code>InputStream</code>. The encoding\n is recognized automatically.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMetaFactory.html

XMPMetaImpl appendArrayItem	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block"><span class="descfrmTypeLabel">Description copied from interface: <code><a href="../../../../../com/itextpdf/kernel/xmp/XMPMeta.html#appendArrayItem-java.lang.String-java.lang.String-com.itextpdf.kernel.xmp.options.PropertyOptions-java.lang.String-com.itextpdf.kernel.xmp.options.PropertyOptions-">XMPMeta</a></code></span></div><br><br><div class="block">Simplifies the construction of an array by not requiring that you pre-create an empty array.\n The array that is assigned is created automatically if it does not yet exist. XMPMetaImpl getArrayItem	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block"><span class="descfrmTypeLabel">Description copied from interface: <code><a href="../../../../../com/itextpdf/kernel/xmp/XMPMeta.html#getArrayItem-java.lang.String-java.lang.String-int-">XMPMeta</a></code></span></div><br><br><div class="block">Provides access to items within an array. XMPMetaImpl getLocalizedText	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block"><span class="descfrmTypeLabel">Description copied from interface: <code><a href="../../../../../com/itextpdf/kernel/xmp/XMPMeta.html#getLocalizedText-java.lang.String-java.lang.String-java.lang.String-java.lang.String-">XMPMeta</a></code></span></div><br><br><div class="block">These functions provide convenient support for localized text properties, including a number\n of special and obscure aspects. Localized text properties are stored in alt-text arrays. They\n allow multiple concurrent localizations of a property value, for example a document title or\n copyright in several languages. The most important aspect of these functions is that they\n select an appropriate array item based on one or two RFC 3066 language tags. One of these\n languages, the "specific" language, is preferred and selected if there is an exact match. For\n many languages it is also possible to define a "generic" language that may be used if there\n is no specific language match. The generic language must be a valid RFC 3066 primary subtag,\n or the empty string. For example, a specific language of "en-US" should be used in the US,\n and a specific language of "en-UK" should be used in England. It is also appropriate to use\n "en" as the generic language in each case. If a US document goes to England, the "en-US"\n title is selected by using the "en" generic language and the "en-UK" specific language. It is\n considered poor practice, but allowed, to pass a specific language that is just an RFC 3066\n primary tag. For example "en" is not a good specific language, it should only be used as a\n generic language. Passing "i" or "x" as the generic language is also considered poor practice\n but allowed. Advice from the W3C about the use of RFC 3066 language tags can be found at:\n http://www.w3.org/International/articles/language-tags/\n <p>\n<em>Note:</em> RFC 3066 language tags must be treated in a case insensitive manner. The XMP\n Toolkit does this by normalizing their capitalization:\n <ul>\n<li> The primary subtag is lower case, the suggested practice of ISO 639.\n <li> All 2 letter secondary subtags are upper case, the suggested practice of ISO 3166.\n <li> All other subtags are lower case. The XMP specification defines an artificial language,\n <li>"x-default", that is used to explicitly denote a default item in an alt-text array.\n </li></li></li></li></ul>\n The XMP toolkit normalizes alt-text arrays such that the x-default item is the first item.\n The SetLocalizedText function has several special features related to the x-default item, see\n its description for details. The selection of the array item is the same for GetLocalizedText\n and SetLocalizedText:\n <ul>\n<li> Look for an exact match with the specific language.\n <li> If a generic language is given, look for a partial match.\n <li> Look for an x-default item.\n <li> Choose the first item.\n </li></li></li></li></ul>\n A partial match with the generic language is where the start of the item's language matches\n the generic string and the next character is '-'. An exact match is also recognized as a\n degenerate case. It is fine to pass x-default as the specific language. In this case,\n selection of an x-default item is an exact match by the first rule, not a selection by the\n 3rd rule. The last 2 rules are fallbacks used when the specific and generic languages fail to\n produce a match. <code>getLocalizedText</code> returns information about a selected item in\n an alt-text array. The array item is selected according to the rules given above.\n\n <em>Note:</em> In a future version of this API a method\n                using Java <code>java.lang.Locale</code> will be added.</p></div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMetaImpl.html
XMPMetaImpl setLocalizedText	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block"><span class="descfrmTypeLabel">Description copied from interface: <code><a href="../../../../../com/itextpdf/kernel/xmp/XMPMeta.html#setLocalizedText-java.lang.String-java.lang.String-java.lang.String-java.lang.String-java.lang.String-com.itextpdf.kernel.xmp.options.PropertyOptions-">XMPMeta</a></code></span></div><br><br><div class="block">Modifies the value of a selected item in an alt-text array. Creates an appropriate array item\n if necessary, and handles special cases for the x-default item. If the selected item is from\n a match with the specific language, the value of that item is modified. If the existing value\n of that item matches the existing value of the x-default item, the x-default item is also\n modified. If the array only has 1 existing item (which is not x-default), an x-default item\n is added with the given value. If the selected item is from a match with the generic language\n and there are no other generic matches, the value of that item is modified. If the existing\n value of that item matches the existing value of the x-default item, the x-default item is\n also modified. If the array only has 1 existing item (which is not x-default), an x-default\n item is added with the given value. If the selected item is from a partial match with the\n generic language and there are other partial matches, a new item is created for the specific\n language. The x-default item is not modified. If the selected item is from the last 2 rules\n then a new item is created for the specific language. If the array only had an x-default\n item, the x-default item is also modified. If the array was empty, items are created for the\n specific language and x-default.\n\n <em>Note:</em> In a future version of this API a method\n                using Java <code>java.lang.Locale</code> will be added.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMetaImpl.html
XMPMetaImpl getProperty	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block"><span class="descfrmTypeLabel">Description copied from interface: <code><a href="../../../../../com/itextpdf/kernel/xmp/XMPMeta.html#getProperty-java.lang.String-java.lang.String-">XMPMeta</a></code></span></div><br><br><div class="block">The property value getter-methods all take a property specification: the first two parameters\n are always the top level namespace URI (the "schema" namespace) and the basic name\n of the property being referenced. See the introductory discussion of path expression usage\n for more information.\n <p>\n All of the functions return an object inherited from <code>PropertyBase</code> or\n <code>null</code> if the property does not exists. The result object contains the value of\n the property and option flags describing the property. Arrays and the non-leaf levels of\n nodes do not have values.\n <p>\n See <a href="../../../../../com/itextpdf/kernel/xmp/options/PropertyOptions.html" title="class in com.itextpdf.kernel.xmp.options"><code>PropertyOptions</code></a> for detailed information about the options.\n <p>\n This is the simplest property getter, mainly for top level simple properties or after using\n the path composition functions in XMPPathFactory.</p></p></p></div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMetaImpl.html

XMPMetaImpl getQualifier	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block"><span class="descfrmTypeLabel">Description copied from interface: <code><a href="../../../../../com/itextpdf/kernel/xmp/XMPMeta.html#getQualifier-java.lang.String-java.lang.String-java.lang.String-java.lang.String-">XMPMeta</a></code></span></div><br><br><div class="block">Provides access to a qualifier attached to a property. See the introductory discussion of qualified properties for more\n information.\n <p>\n The names of qualifiers should be XML qualified names, that is within an XML namespace. The\n path syntax for a qualified name uses the namespace prefix. This is unreliable since the\n prefix is never guaranteed. The URI is the formal name, the prefix is just a local shorthand\n in a given sequence of XML text.\n <p>\n<em>Note:</em> Qualifiers are only supported for simple leaf properties at this time.</p></p></div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMetaImpl.html

XMPMetaImpl sort	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block"><span class="descfrmTypeLabel">Description copied from interface: <code><a href="../../../../../com/itextpdf/kernel/xmp/XMPMeta.html#sort--">XMPMeta</a></code></span></div><br><br><div class="block">Sorts the complete datamodel according to the following rules:\n <ul>\n<li>Schema nodes are sorted by prefix.\n                <li>Properties at top level and within structs are sorted by full name, that is\n                        prefix + local name.\n                <li>Array items are not sorted, even if they have no certain order such as bags.\n                <li>Qualifier are sorted, with the exception of "xml:lang" and/or "rdf:type"\n                        that stay at the top of the list in that order.\n </li></li></li></li></ul></div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMetaImpl.html

XMPPathFactory composeStructFieldPath	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Compose the path expression for a field in a struct. The result can be added to the\n path of</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPPathFactory.html
XMPPathFactory composeQualifierPath	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Compose the path expression for a qualifier.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPPathFactory.html
XMPPathFactory composeLangSelector	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Compose the path expression to select an alternate item by language. The\n path syntax allows two forms of "content addressing" that may\n be used to select an item in an array of alternatives. The form used in\n ComposeLangSelector lets you select an item in an alt-text array based on\n the value of its <tt>xml:lang</tt> qualifier. The other form of content\n addressing is shown in ComposeFieldSelector. \note ComposeLangSelector\n does not supplant SetLocalizedText or GetLocalizedText. They should\n generally be used, as they provide extra logic to choose the appropriate\n language and maintain consistency with the 'x-default' value.\n ComposeLangSelector gives you an path expression that is explicitly and\n only for the language given in the langName parameter.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPPathFactory.html
XMPPathFactory	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Utility services for the metadata object. It has only public static functions, you cannot create\n an object. These are all functions that layer cleanly on top of the kernel XMP toolkit.\n \n These functions provide support for composing path expressions to deeply nested properties. The\n functions XMPMeta such as getProperty(),\n getArrayItem() and getStructField() provide easy access to top\n level simple properties, items in top level arrays, and fields of top level structs. They do not\n provide convenient access to more complex things like fields several levels deep in a complex\n struct, or fields within an array of structs, or items of an array that is a field of a struct.\n These functions can also be used to compose paths to top level array items or struct fields so\n that you can use the binary accessors like getPropertyAsInteger().\n \n You can use these functions is to compose a complete path expression, or all but the last\n component. Suppose you have a property that is an array of integers within a struct. You can\n access one of the array items like this:\n \n\n\n      String path = XMPPathFactory.composeStructFieldPath (schemaNS, "Struct", fieldNS,\n          "Array");\n      String path += XMPPathFactory.composeArrayItemPath (schemaNS, "Array" index);\n      PropertyInteger result = xmpObj.getPropertyAsInteger(schemaNS, path);\n \n You could also use this code if you want the string form of the integer:\n \n\n      String path = XMPPathFactory.composeStructFieldPath (schemaNS, "Struct", fieldNS,\n          "Array");\n      PropertyText xmpObj.getArrayItem (schemaNS, path, index);\n \n\n\nNote: It might look confusing that the schemaNS is passed in all of the calls above.\n This is because the XMP toolkit keeps the top level "schema" namespace separate from\n the rest of the path expression.\n Note: These methods are much simpler than in the C++-API, they don't check the given\n path or array indices.</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPPathFactory.html
XMPPathParser	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Parser for XMP XPaths.</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPPathParser.html
XMPPathSegment XMPPathSegment	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Constructor with initial values.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPPathSegment.html
XMPPathSegment	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>A segment of a parsed XMPPath.</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPPathSegment.html
XMPProperty	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>This interface is used to return a text property together with its and options.</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPProperty.html
XMPPropertyInfo	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>This interface is used to return a property together with its path and namespace.\n It is returned when properties are iterated with the XMPIterator.</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPPropertyInfo.html
XMPSchemaRegistry registerNamespace	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Register a namespace URI with a suggested prefix. It is not an error if\n the URI is already registered, no matter what the prefix is. If the URI\n is not registered but the suggested prefix is in use, a unique prefix is\n created from the suggested one. The actual registeed prefix is always\n returned. The function result tells if the registered prefix is the\n suggested one.\n <p>\n Note: No checking is presently done on either the URI or the prefix.</p></div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPSchemaRegistry.html
XMPSchemaRegistry getNamespacePrefix	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Obtain the prefix for a registered namespace URI.\n <p>\n It is not an error if the namespace URI is not registered.</p></div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPSchemaRegistry.html
XMPSchemaRegistry getNamespaceURI	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Obtain the URI for a registered namespace prefix.\n <p>\n It is not an error if the namespace prefix is not registered.</p></div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPSchemaRegistry.html
XMPSchemaRegistry deleteNamespace	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Deletes a namespace from the registry.\n <p>\n Does nothing if the URI is not registered, or if the namespaceURI\n parameter is null or the empty string.\n <p>\n Note: Not yet implemented.</p></p></div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPSchemaRegistry.html
XMPSchemaRegistry resolveAlias	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Determines if a name is an alias, and what it is aliased to.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPSchemaRegistry.html
XMPSchemaRegistry findAliases	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Collects all aliases that are contained in the provided namespace.\n If nothing is found, an empty array is returned.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPSchemaRegistry.html
XMPSchemaRegistry findAlias	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Searches for registered aliases.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPSchemaRegistry.html
XMPSchemaRegistry	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The schema registry keeps track of all namespaces and aliases used in the XMP\n metadata. At initialisation time, the default namespaces and default aliases\n are automatically registered. Namespaces must be registered before\n used in namespace URI parameters or path expressions. Within the XMP Toolkit\n the registered namespace URIs and prefixes must be unique. Additional\n namespaces encountered when parsing RDF are automatically registered. The\n namespace URI should always end in an XML name separator such as '/' or '#'.\n This is because some forms of RDF shorthand catenate a namespace URI with an\n element name to form a new URI.\n \nAliases in XMP serve the same purpose as Windows file shortcuts,\n Macintosh file aliases, or UNIX file symbolic links. The aliases are simply\n multiple names for the same property. One distinction of XMP aliases is that\n they are ordered, there is an alias name pointing to an actual name. The\n primary significance of the actual name is that it is the preferred name for\n output, generally the most widely recognized name.\n \n The names that can be aliased in XMP are restricted. The alias must be a top\n level property name, not a field within a structure or an element within an\n array. The actual may be a top level property name, the first element within\n a top level array, or the default element in an alt-text array. This does not\n mean the alias can only be a simple property. It is OK to alias a top level\n structure or array to an identical top level structure or array, or to the\n first item of an array of structures.</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPSchemaRegistry.html
XMPSchemaRegistryImpl registerNamespace	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block"><span class="descfrmTypeLabel">Description copied from interface: <code><a href="../../../../../com/itextpdf/kernel/xmp/XMPSchemaRegistry.html#registerNamespace-java.lang.String-java.lang.String-">XMPSchemaRegistry</a></code></span></div><br><br><div class="block">Register a namespace URI with a suggested prefix. It is not an error if\n the URI is already registered, no matter what the prefix is. If the URI\n is not registered but the suggested prefix is in use, a unique prefix is\n created from the suggested one. The actual registeed prefix is always\n returned. The function result tells if the registered prefix is the\n suggested one.\n <p>\n Note: No checking is presently done on either the URI or the prefix.</p></div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPSchemaRegistryImpl.html

XMPSerializerHelper serialize	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Static method to serialize the metadata object. XMPUtils removeProperties	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Remove multiple properties from an XMP object.\n \n RemoveProperties was created to support the File Info dialog's Delete\n button, and has been been generalized somewhat from those specific needs.\n It operates in one of three main modes depending on the schemaNS and\n propName parameters:\n \n <ul>\n<li> Non-empty <code>schemaNS</code> and <code>propName</code> - The named property is\n removed if it is an external property, or if the \n flag <code>doAllProperties</code> option is true. It does not matter whether the\n named property is an actual property or an alias.\n \n <li> Non-empty <code>schemaNS</code> and empty <code>propName</code> - The all external\n properties in the named schema are removed. Internal properties are also\n removed if the flag <code>doAllProperties</code> option is set. In addition,\n aliases from the named schema will be removed if the flag <code>includeAliases</code> \n option is set.\n \n <li> Empty <code>schemaNS</code> and empty <code>propName</code> - All external properties in\n all schema are removed. Internal properties are also removed if the \n flag <code>doAllProperties</code> option is passed. Aliases are implicitly handled\n because the associated actuals are internal if the alias is.\n </li></li></li></ul>\n \n It is an error to pass an empty <code>schemaNS</code> and non-empty <code>propName</code>.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPUtils.html
XMPUtils appendProperties	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block">Alias without the new option <code>deleteEmptyValues</code>.</div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPUtils.html
XMPUtils appendProperties	A										<section class="prog__container"><p><div class="block"><p>Append properties from one XMP object to another.\n \n <p>XMPUtils#appendProperties was created to support the File Info dialog's Append button, and\n has been been generalized somewhat from those specific needs. It appends information from one\n XMP object (source) to another (dest). The default operation is to append only external\n properties that do not already exist in the destination. The flag \n <code>doAllProperties</code> can be used to operate on all properties, external and internal.\n The flag <code>replaceOldValues</code> option can be used to replace the values \n of existing properties. The notion of external\n versus internal applies only to top level properties. The keep-or-replace-old notion applies\n within structs and arrays as described below.\n <ul>\n<li>If <code>replaceOldValues</code> is true then the processing is restricted to the top \n level properties. The processed properties from the source (according to \n <code>doAllProperties</code>) are propagated to the destination, \n replacing any existing values.Properties in the destination that are not in the source \n are left alone.\n\n <li>If <code>replaceOldValues</code> is not passed then the processing is more complicated. \n Top level properties are added to the destination if they do not already exist. \n If they do exist but differ in form (simple/struct/array) then the destination is left alone.\n If the forms match, simple properties are left unchanged while structs and arrays are merged.\n \n <li>If <code>deleteEmptyValues</code> is passed then an empty value in the source XMP causes\n the corresponding destination XMP property to be deleted. The default is to treat empty \n values the same as non-empty values. An empty value is any of a simple empty string, an array\n with no items, or a struct with no fields. Qualifiers are ignored.\n </li></li></li></ul>\n<p>The detailed behavior is defined by the following pseudo-code:\n <blockquote>\n<pre>\n    appendProperties ( sourceXMP, destXMP, doAllProperties, \n                        replaceOldValues, deleteEmptyValues ):\n       for all source schema (top level namespaces):\n          for all top level properties in sourceSchema:\n             if doAllProperties or prop is external:\n                appendSubtree ( sourceNode, destSchema, replaceOldValues, deleteEmptyValues )\n \n    appendSubtree ( sourceNode, destParent, replaceOldValues, deleteEmptyValues ):\n        if deleteEmptyValues and source value is empty:\n            delete the corresponding child from destParent\n        else if sourceNode not in destParent (by name):\n           copy sourceNode's subtree to destParent\n        else if replaceOld:\n            delete subtree from destParent\n            copy sourceNode's subtree to destParent\n        else:\n            // Already exists in dest and not replacing, merge structs and arrays\n            if sourceNode and destNode forms differ:\n                return, leave the destNode alone\n            else if form is a struct:\n                for each field in sourceNode:\n                    AppendSubtree ( sourceNode.field, destNode, replaceOldValues )\n            else if form is an alt-text array:\n                copy new items by "xml:lang" value into the destination\n            else if form is an array:\n                copy new items by value into the destination, ignoring order and duplicates\n </pre>\n</blockquote>\n<p><em>Note:</em> appendProperties can be expensive if replaceOldValues is not passed and \n the XMP contains large arrays. The array item checking described above is n-squared. \n Each source item is checked to see if it already exists in the destination, \n without regard to order or duplicates.\n <p>Simple items are compared by value and "xml:lang" qualifier, other qualifiers are ignored.\n Structs are recursively compared by field names, without regard to field order. Arrays are\n compared by recursively comparing all items.</p></p></p></p></p></div></p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPUtils.html

XMPVersionInfo	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>XMP Toolkit Version Information.\n \n Version information for the XMP toolkit is stored in the jar-library and available through a\n runtime call, XMPMetaFactory.getVersionInfo(),  addition static version numbers are\n defined in "version.properties".</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPVersionInfo.html
